title: Introduction to SimEngine
text: goal many statistical simulations compare behavior two statistical methods; use framework demonstrate SimEngine workflow. statistical simulations type include three basic phases: (1) generate data, (2) run one methods using generated data, (3) compare performance methods. briefly illustrate phases implemented using , use simple example estimating rate parameter λ\lambda Poisson(λ)\text{Poisson}(\lambda) distribution. anchor simulation real-world situation, one can imagine sample size nn Poisson distribution models number patients admitted daily hospital course nn consecutive days. Suppose data consist nn independent identically distributed observations X1,X2,…,XnX_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n drawn Poisson(λ\lambda) distribution. Since λ\lambda parameter Poisson distribution equal mean variance, one may ask whether sample mean (denoted λ̂M,n\hat{\lambda}_{M,n}) sample variance (denoted λ̂V,n\hat{\lambda}_{V,n}) better estimator λ\lambda.

what: 2) Code a function to generate data
title: Introduction to SimEngine
text: Many simulations involve function creates dataset designed mimic real-world data-generating mechanism. , write test simple function generate sample n observations Poisson distribution λ=20\lambda = 20.
code: create_data <- function(n) {   return(rpois(n=n, lambda=20)) }  create_data(n=10) #>  [1] 24 15 19 22 25 11 16 18 17 16

title: Introduction to SimEngine
text: SimEngine, functions declared (loaded via source()) automatically stored simulation object simulation runs. example, test sample mean sample variance estimators λ\lambda parameter. simplicity, write single function use type argument specify estimator use.
code: est_lambda <- function(dat, type) {   if (type=="M") { return(mean(dat)) }   if (type=="V") { return(var(dat)) } } dat <- create_data(n=1000) est_lambda(dat=dat, type="M") #> [1] 19.952 est_lambda(dat=dat, type="V") #> [1] 20.02172

title: Introduction to SimEngine
text: Often, wish run simulation multiple times. refer run simulation replicate. may wish vary certain features simulation replicates. example, perhaps choose vary sample size estimator used estimate λ\lambda. refer features vary simulation levels; example , simulation levels sample size (n) estimator (estimator). refer values simulation level can take level values; example , n level values 10, 100, 1000, estimator level values "M" (“sample mean”) "V" (“sample variance”). default, SimEngine runs one simulation replicate combination level values — case, six combinations — although user typically want increase ; 1,000 10,000 replicates per combination typical. code: sim %<>% set_levels(   estimator = c("M", "V"),   n = c(10, 100, 1000) )

title: Introduction to SimEngine
text: simulation script user-written function assembles pieces (generating data, analyzing data, returning results) code flow single simulation replicate. Within script, current simulation level values can referenced using special variable L. instance, running example, first simulation replicate running, L$estimator equal "M" L$n equal 10. next replicate, L$estimator equal "M" L$n equal 100, , level value combinations run. simulation script automatically access functions objects declared global environment. simulation script always return list containing one key-value pairs, keys syntactically valid names. values may simple data types (numbers, character strings, boolean values) complex data types (lists, dataframes, model objects, etc.); see Advanced Usage documentation handle complex data types. Note example, estimators coded instead two different functions called within script using use_method() function.
code: sim %<>% set_script(function() {   dat <- create_data(n=L$n)   lambda_hat <- est_lambda(dat=dat, type=L$estimator)   return (list("lambda_hat"=lambda_hat)) })

title: SimEngine 1.2.0
text: Added batch() function, allows sharing data objects simulation replicates. Essentially, allows take simulation replicates divide “batches”; replicates given batch share single set objects. common use case simulation involves generating one dataset, analyzing using multiple methods, repeating number times.
